title: Urbanisation-driven land degradation and socioeconomic challenges in peri-urban areas: Insights from Southern Europe
abstract: Climate change and landscape transformation have led to rapid expansion of peri-urban areas globally, representing new 'laboratories' for the study of human-nature relationships aiming at land degradation management. This paper contributes to the debate on human-driven land degradation processes by highlighting how natural and socioeconomic forces trigger soil depletion and environmental degradation in peri-urban areas. The aim was to classify and synthesise the interactions of urbanisation-driven factors with direct or indirect, on-site or off-site, and short-term or century-scale impacts on land degradation, focussing on Southern Europe as a paradigmatic case to address this issue. Assuming complex and multifaceted interactions among influencing factors, a relevant contribution to land degradation was shown to derive from socioeconomic drivers, the most important of which were population growth and urban sprawl. Viewing peri-urban areas as socio-environmental systems adapting to intense socioeconomic transformations, these factors were identified as forming complex environmental 'syndromes' driven by urbanisation. Based on this classification, we suggested three key measures to support future land management in Southern European peri-urban areas.

motivations: Rapid expansion of peri-urban areas globally has led to increased land degradation and socioeconomic challenges.
There is a need to understand the complex interactions between natural and socioeconomic forces driving land degradation in peri-urban areas.
objectives: Classify and synthesize the interactions of urbanisation-driven factors impacting land degradation in peri-urban areas.
Highlight the role of socioeconomic drivers in land degradation processes.
Identify key measures to support future land management in Southern European peri-urban areas.
methods: Analyze the complex interactions among influencing factors driving land degradation in peri-urban areas.
Focus on Southern Europe as a paradigmatic case to address the issue of urbanisation-driven land degradation.
results: Socioeconomic drivers, particularly population growth and urban sprawl, significantly contribute to land degradation in peri-urban areas.
Peri-urban areas can be viewed as socio-environmental systems adapting to intense socioeconomic transformations.
Three key measures are proposed to support future land management in Southern European peri-urban areas.
